Award.AwardTitle: Design and Growth of Si-based Spintronic Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to design and grow new Si-based spintronic materials,
namely Mn doped digital ferromagnetic and trilayer heterostructures, and Mn/Si superlattices. These materials are expected to exhibit high spin polarization, high Curie temperature, and large magnetoresistance. The approaches include first principles calculations to design optimum structural configurations and investigate effects of defects and imperfections; synthesis using hybrid magnetron sputtering/e-beam evaporation and molecular beam epitaxy techniques; and structural and magnetic characterizations.

Intellectual Merits:

This project has several intellectual merits: design and realization of a new class of Sibased spintronic materials; an in-depth understanding of the magnetic interactions and origins of ferromagnetism in the proposed material systems; prescriptions for tuning magnetic coupling between the transition metal atoms in Si-based quantum structures by co-doping holes; and calculations and measurements of magneto-transport properties in proposed heterostructures.

Broader Impact:

This project will have broad impacts on technological advancements, and on education
and training. The proposed materials provide a new paradigm for fabricating spintronic devices such as sensors, switches, memory and other integrated chips with superior performance than the current metal-based devices. Integration with the mature Si-technology, the backbone of high-tech industries, will greatly speed up the development and employment of such devices. The technological advancements will have profound social and economical impacts. Students will be exposed to extensive knowledge of electronic and magnetic properties of spintronic materials through combined theoretical and experimental efforts. The training will help to shape them into future academic and industrial leaders and sustain the U.S. leadership in spintronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There has been tremendous recent interests in spintronics, which utilizes the electron spin degree of freedom for information manipulation, storage, and transmission. Essential for spintronics are materials with high spin polarization, or large imbalance of carrier populations with opposite spins. In non-magnetic metals such as copper or gold, the spin polarization is zero. Ordinary magnetic metals such as iron, cobalt, and nickel have finite spin polarizations. In a special class of materials known as half metals, one spin channel is conducting while the oppositely oriented spin state behaves like a semiconductor, thus possessing the maximum spin polarization of 100%. The objective of this research is to design and explore half-metallic properties in new Si-based spintronic materials.

 

We have designed and investigated several types of half-metallic nanostructures. They include doping of manganese (Mn) into silicon (Si) to form a single layer, three-layer (trilayer) or multiple-layer (superlattice) thin film structures or MnSi alloys with dilute Mn content. Characteristics of the interesting electronic and magnetic properties have been explored, including the ordering temperature, the size of the energy gap in the semiconducting channel of the half metal, and the effect of magnetic coupling between transition metal dopants, etc. The physical origins of these fascinating properties have also been studied. The half-metallic properties have been shown to be robust against certain types of structural defects. Experimentally grown samples of dilute Mn-doped Si alloys and thin films have shown encouraging evidence of ferromagnetism that persists above room temperature.

 

One half-metallic trilayer example is shown in the figure.  It consists of two layers of Mn doped in Si and a layer of either aluminum (Al) or gallium (Ga) in between the Mn layers. The Mn atoms are not substituting any Si atoms. They occupy the open spaces in Si, the so-called interstitial sites, which are energetically favorable. These results suggest that half metallic Si-based trilayers and superlattices are now much more promising. By stacking two trilayers and using a magnetic field to control the spin of the metallic channel in one stack relative to the other, this design will enable switching on and off the current passing through the composite trilayer structure.

 

Additionally, we have investigated a number of other related systems and phenomena, including ferromagnetism in another dilute magnetic semiconductor of ZnO doped with Mn, half-metallic properties of Li-based half Heusler alloys, effect of magnetic configuration on spin-transport, and magnetic vortices, etc.

 

These results offer a potentially promising new paradigm for Si-based spintronic devices. Such devices would consume less power and more reliably store the information coded by spin orientations. Since Si is the backbone of “high-tech” industries, it will be possible to utilize the mature Si technologies to expedite the deployment of spintronics.

 

Our results have been published in many top journal articles, as well as invited review papers and a monograph. One patent has been awarded. The findings have been presented in numerous invited talks at national and international conferences and research institutes. Our work has already attracted attention from the community, with a number of new international collaborative efforts established, as well as industrial interests from companies.
